I was looking at The TRAP - full circle and got inspired to pose a similar question in regards to the turret debate, initially discussed in Who’s tossing a turret on this thing?. What does everyone think? What was the value of having a turret this year?

  • Bot was designed with a turret, it was worth it!
  • Bot was designed with a turret, we regret it!
  • Bot was designed without a turret, it was worth it!
  • Bot was designed without a turret, we regret it!

Surma","username":"CooperSurma","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/coopersurma/{size}/232004_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-10T18:27:47.150Z","cooked":"

IMO the issue with turrets year-over-year is that they add a high amount of weight and complexity for a pretty marginal benefit compared to just turning to face the goal (especially with swerve and/or a good driver). Plus, turrets often require other aspects of the robot to be designed around them, leading to an overall less optimized design

We very briefly discussed a turret at the beginning of the season but didn’t think the benefits outweighed the cost. We definitely knew there would be teams with more resources than ours that would pursue it (to varying degrees of success) but we decided it wasn’t for us this year.

Overall I think the solution we ended up (full vertical shooter rotation, horizontal alignment done with robot drive) with worked pretty good though. Even if you did face defense while shooting (one of the main reasons for having a turret), the field had enough places to shoot from and enough protected zones that there wasn’t a huge benefit in defense styles that blocked scoring directly (most blocked cycling instead).

It seams like the swerve modules coupled with self localization make it so that the entire robot is the turret. On our team there was a disagreement as to what side of the robot was the front. Some said it was the intake side because that always faced away from the drivers station, others said it was the side the launcher shot out of because that was the “business” end of the robot. The whole thing was even more complicated because we scored in the amp by reversing our launcher and launching out the intake side of the robot.

We had two turret bearings fail this season.

Every turret we have built dating back to at least 2005 was built using a single, X-contact, thin section bearing.

This season we used the same 11" ID. 11.5" OD Lily thin section bearings we successfully used in 2022.

This season right before playoffs at the Houston district event the separator in the bearing was noticed to have moved up from its normal position, which allowed all of the balls to fall out of the bearing. We added a few makeshift components to help constrain the turret and ran through the rest of the event with no major affect on our performance. Once back at home we continued to practice with this failed turret bearing for 4 days before we replaced it.

We thought the bearing failed due to a very hard hit in a qualification match at Houston where our shooter hit another robot that was already hanging on the chain. For this reason we did not install parts that we designed to help retain the bearing ball separator on the other robot that competed at Space City because we didn’t want to add the weight.

The next week at FiT Champs we noticed the separator had floated up again and we lost all of the balls in the turret very early into qualifications. We installed the same parts we installed in Houston and ran the rest of the event with a failed turret bearing again.

For worlds we replaced the bearing with just a 1/4" thick Delrin ring, this wasn’t as efficient as the the thin section bearing but with a Kraken driving the turret there wasn’t a hit in performance.

We still don’t really know what was causing these failures. We have used hundreds of thin-section bearings in robots at NASA and have never seen this failure mode (granted we typically use higher quality Kaydon and SIlverthin branded bearings.) It could be a quality issue, especially with these bearings being produced in early 2022 when there was still global supply issues with motion components like these, it could be due to us retaining the bearing slightly differently than on past robots, it could be some other issue. We intend to investigate this in the off season.

We had a turret but it could only feed from one direction and we couldn’t run it snappy enough that it gave an advantage over just using our swerve as our aiming system. I guess it could be said it was useful against “pinning” defense where we couldn’t move out chassis? But overall for us, it was not worth it. If we went with a more solid and rigid design, we could’ve gotten the bot out faster, had maybe a bit more accurate of a shot, could’ve made sure our intake could score in trap, and climbing would have been WAY easier. If we didn’t have a turret, we could’ve climbed for sure, but instead we opted for a not very useful turret, leading to less RP and a not as great performance. Next year I think we’re for sure going with something simpler, we always try to bite off more than we can chew

Our controls layout is one stick for field-centric translation, and another stick to point the front of the robot to a heading (I think the equivalent control scheme is first-person-shooter, but I’ve never played any). This means that the robot “front” is whichever side faces away from the glass when you push the heading stick forward.
